Package fr.istic.cartaylor.implementation

Class PartImpl

java.lang.Object
fr.istic.cartaylor.implementation.PartImpl
All Implemented Interfaces:
Part, PropertyManager
Direct Known Subclasses:
ConfigurationTest.AA, ConfigurationTest.AB, ConfigurationTest.BA, ConfigurationTest.BB, PartTest.ConcretePart
public abstract class PartImpl
extends java.lang.Object
implements Part
Implementation for the Part type. This abstract class must be extended for each part type. To set available properties, creates a constructor method with no parameters and calls the PartImpl#addProperty method for each property. If extensions are declared inside a class, it must be static and public. After a subclass is instanced, the PartImpl#setType must be called with the PartType corresponding.
Author:
Arnaud Akoto yao-arnaud.akoto@etudiant.univ-rennes1.fr, Anthony Amiard anthony.amiard@etudiant.univ-rennes1.fr

  • Method Details

    • setType

      public void setType​(PartType type)
      Set the type of the part. Must be done just after creation.
      Parameters:
      type - Type of the part

    • addProperty

      protected void addProperty​(java.lang.String name, java.util.function.Supplier<java.lang.String> getter, java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.String> setter, java.util.Set<java.lang.String> possibleValues)
      Add a property to the part. This method is aimed to be called in subclasses' constructors to define available properties.
      Parameters:
      name - Name of the property
      getter - Method called by PartImpl#getProperty to get the current value.
      setter - Method called by PartImpl#setProperty with the user's new value. If this property has a set of possible values, will be called only if provided value is a possible value. null for a read-only property.
      possibleValues - Set of possible values. Empty set for no value checking, or continuous values.

    • getProperty

      public java.util.Optional<java.lang.String> getProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName)
      Returns the optional value of a property. If the object does not support that property then an empty optional is returned.
      Specified by:
      getProperty in interface PropertyManager
      Parameters:
      propertyName - the property to read
      Returns:
      On optional storing the value set for property, or an empty optional if the property is not supported

    • setProperty

      public void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName, java.lang.String propertyValue)
      Sets the value of a given property. If there is not such property, or if it not writable, or if the value is invalid then an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.
      Specified by:
      setProperty in interface PropertyManager
      Parameters:
      propertyName - Name of the property
      propertyValue - Value of the property
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - (see above)

    • getAvailablePropertyValues

      public java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getAvailablePropertyValues​(java.lang.String propertyName)
      Returns the immutable set of discrete string values for a given property. For properties that have a non explicit set of possible values (eg double converted to strings), or for a non existing property name, returns an empty set.
      Specified by:
      getAvailablePropertyValues in interface PropertyManager
      Parameters:
      propertyName - a non-null string reference
      Returns:
      an immutable set (see above)
